questions.text: A mother noticed yellowish discoloration of her baby 7 hours after birth. Initially, it was on the face, but now it has spread to the abdomen and thighs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pathological Jaundice

  • Always appears on Day 1
  • Rate of increase: More than 5 mg/day
  • Duration: Usually exceeds 1 week
  • Involvement: Palms and soles are often involved

Physiological Jaundice

  • Never appears on Day 1
  • Rate of increase: Not more than 5 mg/day
  • Duration: Does not exceed 7 days in term babies, 14 days in preterm babies

Breastfeeding Jaundice

  • Cause: Inadequate feeding leading to relative dehydration and jaundice
  • Timing: Usually presents in the first week
  • Note: It is a misnomer

Breast Milk Jaundice

  • Cause: Breast milk inhibits conjugation
  • Timing: Appears in the second week of life
  • Nature: Transient and benign
  • Management: Continue breastfeeding in both breastfeeding and breast milk jaundice

Reference: OP Ghai, Essentials of Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page 168.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old male presents to the hospital with a fever and retro-orbital pain. The patient reports a history of a mosquito bite with white dots. On examination, he has narrow pulse pressure and cold extremities. Which of the following clinical features can be seen in the condition described?
1. Hepatomegaly
2. Pleural Effusion
3. Thrombocytopenia
4. Decreased Hemoglobin
Select the correct answer from the options below:
questions.solution:
Dengue Shock Syndrome

The clinical scenario described suggests Dengue Shock Syndrome:

  • Fever with minor or major hemorrhagic manifestations
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Hemoconcentration
  • Pleural effusion, ascites, or hypoalbuminemia
  • Hypotension
  • Tachycardia
  • Narrow pulse pressure (≤ 20 mmHg)
  • Signs of poor perfusion (cold extremities)

In Dengue Shock Syndrome, there is increased vascular permeability leading to hemoconcentration (increased hematocrit and hemoglobin levels).

Reference: OP Ghai, Essentials of Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page 222.

questions.text: A child has just started to move on all 4 limbs as shown below. When does the following movement begin in a child?
questions.solution:
The child given in the image is crawling, which begins at 8-9 months. In crawling, the abdomen is toughing the ground.

Creeping which involves abdomen lifted off the ground, comes about 1 month later at 9-10 months

Reference: OP Ghai, 10th ed, page 25

questions.text: A child with development delay can ride a tricycle, can copy a circle, can say name, knows own sex, but cannot narrate a story. What is the developmental age?
questions.solution:
Age of Attaining Developmental Milestones:

  • Riding a tricycle: Typically achieved by 3 years of age.
  • Saying full name and gender: Usually attained by 3 years of age.
  • Copying a circle: A milestone reached around 3 years of age.
  • Narrating a story: Generally developed by 4 years of age.

In this scenario, the child is able to perform milestones associated with 3 years of age but is unable to perform milestones expected at 4 years. Therefore, the developmental age of the child should be assessed as 3 years.

Reference: OP Ghai, Essentials of Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Tables 3.1, 3.2, and 3.4.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-week-old baby with complaints of vomiting and polyuria. On examination, the baby is in a state of shock and has hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. The image of the external genitalia shows ambiguous genitalia. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely present in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms described-ambiguous genitalia, shock, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia-are characteristic of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Babies with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present between 10-14 days of age with symptoms like progressive weight loss, anorexia, weakness, polyuria, vomiting, dehydration, and hypotension.
  • Without treatment, they are at risk for shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and potentially death within days or weeks.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring blood levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP).

Reference: OP Ghai, Essentials of Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page 522.

questions.text: A 38-week gestation male infant was precipitously delivered vaginally in the emergency department. The infant's weight and head circumference are less than the 5th percentile, and the length is at the 1st percentile. He presents with hepatosplenomegaly and a petechial rash. Notable laboratory results include thrombocytopenia (platelets of 22,000/mm3) and elevated total and direct bilirubin levels. A CT scan of the head shows bilateral intracranial calcifications, particularly around the basal ganglia, along with obstructive hydrocephalus. Ophthalmologic examination reveals chorioretinitis. What is the most likely cause of the patient's findings?
questions.solution:
• The triad of hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis is a classic presentation for congenital toxoplasmosis.

Regarding other options:

  • Option A (Cytomegalovirus): Intracranial calcifications associated with cytomegalovirus (CMV) are typically in a periventricular distribution and do not usually present with hydrocephalus; though dilated ventricles may occasionally be seen.
  • Option B (Rubella virus): Rubella often presents with a purpuric rash and cataracts but lacks CT findings such as calcifications.
  • Option D (Herpes simplex virus): Herpes simplex virus may present with vesicles or scarring but does not cause intracranial calcifications.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 1st South Asia Edition, Page 1724.

questions.text: A child with HIV presents with features of pneumonia. Which of the following organisms would most commonly be responsible?
questions.solution:
• Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a common opportunistic infection in children with HIV and is one of the earliest AIDS-defining illnesses. It typically occurs between the 3rd and 6th month of life in HIV-infected children.

Reference: Ghai, Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page 225.

questions.text: A 6-week-old neonate was diagnosed with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Investigations revealed elevated bilirubin levels with normal liver enzymes. Phenobarbitone therapy was administered, but there was no improvement in the patient's condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Crigler-Najjar Syndrome Type 1: This condition is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to a complete absence of UDP-glucuronosyl transferase (UDP-GT) activity. The lack of improvement with phenobarbitone therapy, which does not induce any increase in enzyme activity, strongly suggests Crigler-Najjar Syndrome Type 1. It is an autosomal recessive disorder that can lead to severe jaundice and kernicterus, often resulting in death by 18-24 months of age if untreated. Management involves phototherapy, plasmapheresis, and exchange transfusion initially, with liver transplantation as a definitive treatment.

Regarding other options:

  • A. Dubin-Johnson Syndrome: This is a cause of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and involves impaired hepatic excretion of bilirubin, which does not fit the presentation of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in this case.
  • C. Crigler-Najjar Syndrome Type 2: Also known as Arias syndrome, it involves a significant reduction, but not a complete absence, of UDP-GT. Unlike Type 1, jaundice is less severe, and bilirubin levels decrease significantly with phenobarbitone administration.
  • D. Gilbert Syndrome: This is the most common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but it involves only a partial deficiency of UDP-GT and typically presents with mild, recurrent jaundice without the severe symptoms seen in this case.

Reference: OP Ghai, Essentials of Pediatrics, 9th Edition.

questions.text: Calculate the APGAR score in a neonate at 1 min of life, if there is acrocyanosis, grimacing on examination, HR is 110/min, flexed attitude with spontaneous movements of limbs and good cry?
questions.solution:
To calculate the APGAR score for the neonate at 1 minute of life, we evaluate five criteria: Appearance (skin color), Pulse (heart rate), Grimace (reflex irritability), Activity (muscle tone), and Respiration (effort).

Given information:

  • Appearance (Skin Color): Acrocyanosis (body pink, extremities blue) - Score: 1
  • Pulse (Heart Rate): 110/min - Score: 2
  • Grimace (Reflex Irritability): Grimacing on stimulation - Score: 1
  • Activity (Muscle Tone): Flexed attitude with spontaneous movements - Score: 2
  • Respiration (Breathing Effort): Good cry - Score: 2

Let's calculate the total score:

  1. Appearance: 1 point (acrocyanosis)
  2. Pulse: 2 points (HR > 100)
  3. Grimace: 1 point (grimacing)
  4. Activity: 2 points (flexed with spontaneous movements)
  5. Respiration: 2 points (good cry)

Total APGAR score = 1 + 2 + 1 + 2 + 2 = 8

Reference: OP Ghai, 10th edition, page 121, table 9.2

questions.text: A 36-week gestation infant is delivered via cesarean section due to macrosomia and fetal distress. The mother has class D pregestational diabetes (insulin-dependent with vascular disease), and her hemoglobin A1c is 15% (normal is 7%). This infant is at risk for hypocalcemia, cardiomyopathy, polycythemia, and which of the following?
questions.solution:
Infants born to mothers with poorly controlled diabetes are at risk for several complications, including respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Despite the near-term gestational age, the following reasons contribute to this risk:

  • Maternal Hyperglycemia: Leads to fetal hyperinsulinism. High levels of insulin in the fetus inhibit the production of surfactant, a substance necessary for keeping the alveoli open and preventing collapse in the lungs. This antagonistic effect of insulin delays lung maturation.
  • Surfactant Deficiency: Results in RDS because the lungs are not mature enough to function properly at birth, even at 36 weeks of gestation.

Other options:

  • A. Congenital dislocated hip: This condition is unrelated to maternal diabetes and is more associated with mechanical factors or breech presentation.
  • C. Hyperglycemia: Infants of diabetic mothers are typically at risk for hypoglycemia after birth due to high insulin levels, not hyperglycemia.
  • D. Pneumothorax: This can occur as a complication of RDS but is not directly associated with infants of diabetic mothers.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Chapter 127.1; Avery's Diseases of the Newborn, 1st South Asia Edition, Page 653.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with developmental delay is brought to the pediatrician for immunizations. The patient appeared to be developing normally until 18 months of age, when a regression of milestones was noticed. Her head circumference plateaued, resulting in microcephaly. She wrings her hands and has sighing breathing. She is noted to have ataxia and a marked loss of gross motor skills. In addition, she has a loss of language milestones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Rett Syndrome (Choice C) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that primarily affects females. It is characterized by normal early growth and development followed by a slowing of development, loss of purposeful hand movements, hand-wringing movements, loss of speech, ataxia, microcephaly, and breathing abnormalities such as sighing, apnea, and hyperventilation. Symptoms typically emerge between 6-18 months of age, coinciding with the description of regression seen in this patient.

Other options:

  • A. Autism: While autism can involve developmental delays and regression, it typically does not involve microcephaly, ataxia, or loss of motor skills as seen in this patient. Autism primarily affects social interaction and communication without the specific neurological findings seen in Rett syndrome.
  • B. Williams Syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by distinct facial features (e.g., a wide mouth, full lips, a small upturned nose), cardiovascular disease, and an outgoing personality, but it does not include regression after normal development or the specific neurologic symptoms described.
  • D. Turner Syndrome: A condition affecting females, characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, broad chest, and lymphatic abnormalities. It does not involve neurological regression or the hand-wringing stereotypies seen in Rett syndrome.

Reference: Nelson, Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page Number: 3192.

questions.text: A term baby is born after an uncomplicated pregnancy to a 33-year-old mother. At birth, the baby was lethargic with a heart rate (HR) of 40. Oxygen was administered via bag and mask, and the baby was intubated; however, the HR remained at 40 beats/min despite adequate positive-pressure ventilation (PPV). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
According to the neonatal resuscitation algorithm:

  • If the heart rate remains below 60 beats/min despite adequate positive-pressure ventilation (PPV) with 100% oxygen, chest compressions should be initiated.
  • Chest compressions should be started for 30 seconds. If the heart rate is still below 60 beats/min after 60 seconds of PPV and chest compressions, drug therapy with epinephrine is indicated.

Other options:

  • A. Administer IV bicarbonate: This is not the immediate next step in resuscitation for a baby with a low HR despite PPV. Bicarbonate is generally not used in the initial steps of neonatal resuscitation.
  • B. Stimulate the baby again: Stimulation alone is unlikely to increase the heart rate in this situation where the HR is critically low.
  • C. Tracheal suctioning: Suctioning may be considered if there is evidence of an obstructed airway, but in this case, the HR remains low despite adequate PPV, making chest compressions the more appropriate next step.

Reference: NRP 8th Edition Guidelines; Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Chapter 121.

questions.text: Identify the likely diagnosis by looking at the karyotype:
questions.solution:
The karyotype provided shows a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion). This genetic abnormality is characteristic of Cri-du-chat Syndrome (also known as 5p- syndrome).

Cri-du-chat Syndrome (5p- syndrome):

  • It is caused by a deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5.
  • Main features include:
    • Hypotonia (reduced muscle tone).
    • Short stature.
    • Characteristic high-pitched cry that sounds similar to a cat (hence the name "cri-du-chat," which means "cry of the cat" in French).
    • Microcephaly (small head size) with a protruding metopic suture.
    • Hypertelorism (wide-set eyes).
    • Bilateral epicanthic folds.
    • High arched palate.
    • Wide and flat nasal bridge.
    • Intellectual disability.

Other options:

  • A. Bloom Syndrome: Characterized by short stature, photosensitivity, and increased cancer risk, not associated with specific chromosomal deletions like 5p-.
  • B. Fragile X Syndrome: Caused by a trinucleotide repeat (CGG) expansion on the X chromosome, not a chromosomal deletion.
  • C. Prader-Willi Syndrome: Caused by a deletion or uniparental disomy on chromosome 15q11-13, not chromosome 5.

Reference: Nelson, 21st Edition, Table 98.12.

choices.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask the mother to return if danger signs develop.
Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
Consider severe dehydration, start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher center.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. There is no history of fever or blood in the stools. The mother reports the child is irritable and eagerly drinks water when given. On examination, the child has sunken eyes, and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracts within two seconds but not immediately. What is the advised treatment for the child?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests the child has some dehydration based on the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) guidelines:

  • Symptoms of some dehydration include:
  • Thirst (eagerly drinks water)
  • Sunken eyes
  • Restlessness or irritability
  • Skin pinch showing slow retraction (less than 2 seconds but not immediate)

According to the WHO IMCI Plan B for some dehydration:

  • Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) should be administered. The amount of ORS given is 75 mL/kg of the child's body weight.
  • Zinc supplementation is recommended to reduce the duration and severity of diarrhea.
  • Continued breastfeeding and a normal diet should be maintained.
  • The mother should be advised to return if there are any danger signs (like persistent vomiting, lethargy, or worsening symptoms).

Reference:

  • WHO Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) guidelines.
  • Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics.

questions.text: Of the following, all are findings of the condition shown in the chest X-ray below except:
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray described in the question shows an "egg-on-string" appearance, which is characteristic of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA). This condition is marked by the following key features:

  1. Increased Pulmonary Blood Flow (Option A):
    • In TGA, the aorta arises from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle, resulting in the circulation of oxygen-poor blood through the systemic circulation and oxygen-rich blood through the pulmonary circulation. This abnormal configuration often leads to increased pulmonary blood flow, especially as pulmonary vascular resistance decreases after birth.
  2. Narrow Vascular Pedicle (Option B):
    • The "egg-on-string" appearance seen in TGA on a chest X-ray is due to a narrow vascular pedicle, which represents a narrowed superior mediastinum. This is due to the abnormal positioning of the great arteries.
  3. Pulmonary Venous Hypertension (Option C):
    • Pulmonary venous hypertension can occur in TGA, particularly in infants with an intact ventricular septum, as increased pulmonary blood flow elevates pulmonary venous pressures.
  4. Right Atrial Enlargement (Option D):
    • This is not a typical finding in TGA. Instead, left atrial enlargement is more common due to increased pulmonary blood flow and venous return. The "egg-on-string" appearance also indicates abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, but not right atrial enlargement.

Therefore, Option D (Right atrial enlargement) is the correct answer because right atrial enlargement is not typically seen in TGA, while the other options are consistent with the radiological and pathophysiological findings of TGA.

References:

  • Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 2408.
  • Clinical guidelines on the management of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA).

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from her hands, particularly during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. An EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation in this case suggests Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME):

  • Dropping objects from hands: This indicates myoclonic jerks, which are sudden, brief, involuntary muscle contractions. In JME, these jerks typically occur in the morning shortly after awakening.
  • No history of loss of consciousness: In JME, myoclonic jerks usually occur with preserved consciousness, which aligns with the patient's description.
  • Precipitating during morning hours and exams: Myoclonic jerks in JME are often most noticeable in the morning and can be exacerbated by stress, sleep deprivation, and other triggers, such as exams.
  • Family history of epilepsy: JME often has a genetic component, with a positive family history of epilepsy in some cases.
  • EEG findings of epileptic spikes: The presence of generalized polyspike and slow wave discharges on EEG is characteristic of JME.

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the image description suggest bladder exstrophy:

  • Continuous dribbling of urine: This symptom indicates a problem with urinary continence, commonly seen in bladder exstrophy.
  • Protruding bladder with exposed mucosa: This is a classic sign of bladder exstrophy, where the bladder is turned inside out and exposed outside the abdominal wall due to a congenital defect.
  • Anatomical defects associated with bladder exstrophy: These include the following, which are mentioned in the description:
  • Downward displacement of the umbilicus
  • Widely separated pubic rami
  • Separation of the rectus muscles
  • In females, the separation of the two halves of the clitoris and wide separation of the labia; in males, complete epispadias with dorsal chordee

Other Options:

  • Gastroschisis (Option A): This condition involves a defect in the abdominal wall leading to protrusion of abdominal contents, but it does not involve the urinary system or continuous dribbling of urine.
  • Superior vesical fissure (Option C): This is not a commonly used term and does not match the described pathology.
  • Anterior ectopic anus (Option D): This involves the abnormal positioning of the anus, but it does not relate to the described symptoms or findings, such as continuous urine dribbling or exposed bladder mucosa.

Thus, based on the clinical scenario and image description, Bladder exstrophy (Option B) is the most likely diagnosis.

References:

  • Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition.

questions.text: A 2-day-old baby boy is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit due to a high fever with a temperature of 38°C and seizures. Physical examination reveals a newborn baby with wide-set eyes, a small mandible, and a cleft palate. On auscultation of the heart, there is a holosystolic ejection murmur at the fourth intercostal space in the midclavicular line. Serum chemistries show severe hypocalcemia. This syndrome is caused by mutant genes found in which of the following chromosomes?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome).

Key features pointing to DiGeorge syndrome include:

  • Facial dysmorphism: Wide-set eyes, small mandible, and cleft palate are common features.
  • Cardiac abnormalities: The presence of a holosystolic ejection murmur suggests a congenital heart defect, such as TOF or a truncus arteriosus, which are common in DiGeorge syndrome.
  • Severe hypocalcemia: This results from parathyroid hypoplasia, leading to low calcium levels.
  • Increased susceptibility to infections: This is due to thymic hypoplasia or aplasia, causing T-cell immunodeficiency.
  • Seizures: Often secondary to hypocalcemia.

Pathophysiology:

DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a microdeletion on chromosome 22q11.2. This region, known as the DiGeorge chromosomal region (DGCR), contains several genes crucial for the development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches during embryogenesis. Deletion in this region leads to the classical features observed in DiGeorge syndrome.

Other Options:

  • Chromosome 5 (Option A): Associated with Cri-du-chat syndrome.
  • Chromosome 13 (Option B): Associated with Patau syndrome.
  • Chromosome 18 (Option C): Associated with Edwards syndrome.

The disease is sometimes referred to as CATCH22 syndrome due to its characteristic features: Cardiac abnormality, Abnormal facies, Thymic hypoplasia, Cleft palate, and Hypocalcemia, all linked to chromosome 22 deletions.

References:

  • Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Table 98.13.

questions.text: A child presents with brown-colored urine and oliguria for the last 3 days. He has mild facial and pedal edema. His blood pressure is 126/90. He has 2+ proteinuria with >100 red cells/HPF and a few granular casts. His creatinine is 0.9, urea is 56. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical Features:

  • Acute nephritic syndrome: 3 days of symptoms.
  • Brown-colored urine.
  • Oliguria and mild edema.
  • Hypertension: 126/90 mmHg.
  • Proteinuria: 2+.
  • Hematuria: >100 red cells/HPF.
  • Granular casts.

Diagnosis:

  • Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN):
  • Typically follows Group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection.
  • Manifests 1-2 weeks after pharyngitis or 3-6 weeks after pyoderma.
  • Pathological findings:
    • Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli.
    • Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3.
    • Subepithelial humps on electron microscopy.

Management:

  • Sodium restriction and diuretics for renal insufficiency and hypertension.
  • Antibiotic therapy: A 10-day course of penicillin.
  • Complete resolution in most cases within 3-6 weeks, but persistent hematuria and non-nephrotic proteinuria in some.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 2723

choices.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD
Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for severe acute malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):

  • Weight-for-height (Not age): Less than -3 SD.
  • Presence of bipedal edema.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC): Less than 11.5 cm.

Not Criteria for SAM:

  • Weight-for-age: Less than -3 SD is not a specific criterion for SAM; it is used for identifying severe underweight.

References:

  • Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 336

questions.text: A young girl presents with continuous dribbling of urine, although she voids normally. Her parents report she has never been totally dry since birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis and Presentation:

  • Ectopic Ureter: This condition involves a ureter that drains outside the bladder, commonly into the urethra or vagina, leading to continuous urinary dribbling (paradoxical incontinence) despite normal voiding. It is more common in females and can cause urinary tract infections (UTIs) due to urinary stasis.

Alternative Diagnoses:

  • Ureterocele: This involves a cystic dilation of the ureter near its entrance into the bladder. It may present with urinary obstruction or recurrent UTIs, but typically does not cause continuous dribbling of urine.
  • Congenital Megaureter: A dilated ureter that may cause UTIs, urinary stones, hematuria, and flank pain due to urinary stasis, not continuous dribbling.
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux (VUR): Characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the ureter and kidney, leading to recurrent UTIs. It does not typically cause continuous dribbling of urine.

References:

  • Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Pages 2796
  • Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1467

choices.text: Get a hemogram and throat swab done

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby has intermittent stridor and dysphagia since birth. Symptoms worsen with crying or in the prone position and improve when lying supine and calm. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
• Laryngomalacia is suggested by the intermittent stridor and dysphagia since birth, exacerbated by crying and in the supine position, and improving when prone.
  • Management: Most cases of laryngomalacia resolve spontaneously as the child grows and the airway matures. Expectant observation and reassurance are generally sufficient.

References:

  • Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Chapter 413
  • OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Pages 397-398

choices.text: Intravenous Magnesium Sulphate can be considered

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with a family history of bronchial asthma presents with difficulty in breathing, appears anxious, and is using accessory muscles. Her saturation is <90% on 5 L of oxygen via a facemask. Despite receiving 10 puffs of salbutamol via a spacer, her condition has not improved. What are the plans of action for this patient?
questions.solution:
Life-threatening asthma (SpO2 <90% despite oxygen, silent chest, anxiety) requires comprehensive management:

  • Oxygen: Continue supplemental oxygen.
  • Nebulized Salbutamol: Administer nebulized bronchodilators.
  • Intravenous Hydrocortisone: Administer IV corticosteroids (5 mg/kg) to reduce inflammation.
  • Intravenous Magnesium Sulphate: Consider if no improvement (50 mg/kg slow IV infusion).
  • Additional Options: Subcutaneous Terbutaline or Adrenaline, and possible intubation and mechanical ventilation if no clinical improvement.

References:

  • OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 415
  • Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 1st SA Edition, Page 1106

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has chronic cough, foul-smelling bulky and sticky stools, poor weight gain, and a salty taste on kissing. CFTR gene mutation was detected. Which ion abnormality should be checked for confirmation of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Cystic Fibrosis is indicated by symptoms such as chronic cough, steatorrhea, poor weight gain, and a salty taste.
  • Confirmation: Check chloride levels, as CFTR gene mutations lead to chloride channel dysfunction, a key feature in cystic fibrosis.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Chapter 432

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child with recurrent bloody stools, atopic dermatitis-like rash, and petechiae has normal TLC but a platelet count of 20,000/mm3. What is the next best step to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) is indicated by the triad of atopic dermatitis-like rash, recurrent bloody stools indicating recurrent infections, and Petechai due to thrombocytopenia.
  • Diagnosis: Screen for WASp gene expression due to mutations on Chromosome 11p22.23.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Chapter 152, Page 1117

questions.text: A 9-year-old child with recurrent meningococcemia is suspected to have an immunodeficiency. What is the most likely immune deficiency predisposing this child to recurrent N. meningitidis infection?
questions.solution:
Terminal complement deficiencies (C5b-C9) impair formation of the membrane attack complex, leading to increased susceptibility to Neisseria infections.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 1st SA Edition, Page 1288

choices.text: DPT full course should be repeated
Only DT needs to be given now

questions.text: A 1-year-old child reports to you having received the DPT vaccine at 6 weeks but missed subsequent doses. What should be the next vaccination strategy?
questions.solution:
Vaccination Strategy:

  • If a primary dose of DPT, IPV, Hib, PCV, Hep A, Hep B or MR vaccine is missed, subsequent immunization should be given at the next visit as if the usual interval had elapsed.
  • OP Ghai Textbook says 'A delay or lapse in the administration of a dose does not require the schedule to be repeated; the missed dose is administered and the course resumed at the point it was interrupted. Delaying the dose does not affect adversely the rates of seroconversion or titers.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Page 188; WHO Update March 2023; IAP guidebook of immunization, 2018, pg. 87

questions.text: A 6-year-old female child has a non-blanchable, palpable petechial rash on lower limbs and buttocks, with 3+ urinary protein and joint pains. A sore throat was noted 2 weeks prior. What is the therapy of choice?
questions.solution:
The child was having a trigger factor in the form of sore throat & 2 weeks later, she presented with non-blanchable, palpable petechial rash on dependent parts, renal and joint involvement.

This translates to a diagnosis of Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura, HSP- Also known as IgA Vasculitis.

Management of HSP is Conservative- More than 90% improve in about 4 weeks.

Steroids, e.g., Prednisolone are indicated in severe GIT involvement

Reference: OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 661

questions.text: A 3 1/2-year-old child with high fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, red eyes, erythematous papules on the trunk and tongue is suspected to have which complication in the first 7-10 days of illness?
questions.solution:
The clinical description along with the image showing Strawberry Tongue is suggestive of Kawasaki Disease.

  • Myocarditis is the most common clinical complication, frequently encountered in the first

1-2 weeks of illness. Usually subclinical, can sometimes produce CCF and very rarely, mortality

The more dreaded complication is Coronary Artery Aneurysm, occurring between 2nd to 3rd weeks of illness. Can cause mortality and is the overall most common cause of death in KD.

As per OP Ghai 10th Ed, CAAs can occur in 15-25% of untreated KD and even in 3-5% of treated KD patients.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Page 659, Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 191

questions.text: A 6-year-old male with fatigue and mild joint pains has a rash on the hands. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Juvenile Dermatomyositis.

Fatigue is an early sign of muscle weakness. That along with the characteristic Gottron papules in the image suggest a diagnosis of Juvenile Dermatomyositis.

Please note that as per Nelson 21st Ed, 22-58% of JDM patients also have arthralgia and arthritis.

Reference: Nelson 21st Ed, Chapter 184, OP Ghai 10th Ed, Pages 656-657

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with periorbital edema, mild oliguria, and no hypertension has serum albumin <2.5 g/dl, urine protein 3+, and no RBCs or RBC casts. What is the likely histopathological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of 3+ urine protein and hypoalbuminemia with edema indicates a likely diagnosis of Nephrotic Syndrome.

  • Since there is no hematuria or hypertension, it is likely to be Idiopathic Nephrotic Syndrome, most commonly showing a histological pattern of Minimal Change Disease in a 2–8-year-old boy.
  • The disease is so named because the light microscopy shows minimal to no change. However, electron microscopy shows effacement of foot process of podocytes.
  • Oliguria is more commonly seen in Acute Nephritic Syndrome but can sometimes occur in Nephrotic Syndrome also as serum albumin falls and edema worsens.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Pages 500-501.

questions.text: A newborn infant of a 28 year old Primigravida has severe respiratory distress, pulmonary hypoplasia, pseudo epicanthus, flattened ears and nose, and bilateral club feet has abdominal ultrasonography showing enlarged echogenic kidneys with poor corticomedullary differentiation; there are no cysts or hydronephrosis. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The child has pulmonary hypoplasia producing severe respiratory distress, abnormal facies & bilateral clubfeet, with structural renal anomalies. All this suggests a diagnosis of Potter's Syndrome.

Potter syndrome/Potter sequence/oligohydramnios sequence is the characteristic phenotypic features in the neonate caused by oligohydramnios.

The characteristic features include pulmonary hypoplasia (respiratory distress in the newborn), facial appearance (pseudo epicanthus, flattened ears and nose, recessed chin), and limb abnormalities (club feet and hip dislocation).

Types of Potter syndrome

Type I: Associated with ARPKD

Type II: Associated with renal agenesis or hereditary renal dysplasia

Type III: Associated with ADPKD

Type IV: Associated with obstructive uropathy and hydronephrosis

Potter syndrome type 1 occurs in association with ARPKD.

On ultrasonography, patients with ARPKD have enlarged echogenic kidneys without obvious renal cysts whereas ADPKD is associated with macrocysts.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1969

questions.text: A male infant with abdominal distension, crying episodes, no urine output for 10 hours, and a history of UTI in the past. On examination, there is fullness of bladder indicating urinary retention. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Posterior urethral valve (PUV) is one of the most common causes of lower urinary tract obstruction in male children, these children present with dribbling, poor urinary stream, recurrent UTI and palpable bladder. USG shows key-hole appearance, but MCU is diagnostic in such patients.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Page 529

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman gives birth to a female infant who is growth restricted, microcephalic, and has a congenital heart defect. She has had 1 prior miscarriage and reports that she has a 3-year-old son who is abnormally fair, with mental impairment. She also recalls being on a special diet as a child which she subsequently discontinued. Which of the following maternal conditions is most consistent with this history?
questions.solution:
• Maternal PKU (Phenylketonuria) can result in elevated phenylalanine levels during pregnancy, which disrupt fetal development and lead to a range of birth defects including microcephaly, growth restriction, and congenital heart defects.
  • The infant may also show signs of facial dysmorphism similar to fetal alcohol syndrome and hypopigmentation due to lack of pigment formation. Musty odour or mousy odour of urine is also produced.
  • The maternal history of a special diet (often a low-phenylalanine diet) discontinued is consistent with PKU, as it is a condition managed by dietary restrictions.

Maternal Diabetes leads to macrosomia not growth restriction

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 1st SA Edition, Page 637

questions.text: A child is brought with a 2-week history of fever, poor feeding, and irritability. On examination, he has neck rigidity. His sister is already taking treatment for TB. CSF (cerebrospinal fluid) analysis on lumbar puncture is likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
• Tuberculous Meningitis is suggested by the child’s symptoms (fever, neck rigidity, poor feeding, irritability) and the history of contact with a TB patient.
  • In tuberculous meningitis, CSF analysis typically shows:
    • Lymphocytosis: Predominantly lymphocytes are found in the CSF.
    • Low Glucose: CSF glucose levels are decreased due to the consumption by the bacteria.
    • High Protein: CSF protein levels are elevated due to inflammation.

Reference: Nelson 21st Edition, Table 621.1

questions.text: A seven-day-old neonate presents with recurrent seizures. Examination reveals tachycardia, S3 gallop, and a bruit in the anterior fontanelle. Blood investigations are normal. Transcranial USG shows a hypoechoic lesion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Vein of Galen malformation (VGM) is characterized by high-output cardiac failure, bruit in the skull (often in the midline), and a hypoechoic lesion on transcranial ultrasound.
  • Clinical features such as tachycardia, an S3 gallop, and recurrent seizures are consistent with VGM due to the high blood flow and cardiac strain.
  • Transcranial ultrasound showing a hypoechoic lesion supports the diagnosis of VGM.
  • Cause: Abnormal persistence of the median prosencephalic vein (MPV).
  • Treatment: Endoscopic embolization or surgical intervention may be required.

Reference: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 609

questions.text: A three-year-old boy presents to the clinic with poor head control and increased difficulty walking and climbing stairs for the past few months. Upon further investigation, the child's maternal uncle had similar symptoms at the same age and passed away in his late twenties. On physical exam, you notice his calf muscles are enlarged. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, leading to progressive muscle degeneration and weakness.
  • Symptoms typically include poor head control, difficulty walking, and climbing stairs. Calf muscle enlargement (pseudohypertrophy) is characteristic due to fat and collagen deposition rather than muscle tissue.
  • Family history of similar symptoms and early onset, as described in the question, is consistent with DMD.
  • Spinal muscular atrophy type 2 and juvenile dermatomyositis present differently and would not typically show calf muscle hypertrophy or the same progression of symptoms.
  • Type 1 myotonic dystrophy usually presents in older children or adults and has different clinical features.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA edition, pg. 2967

questions.text: An 8-year-old pediatric patient presents with generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS) lasting more than 45 minutes. What should be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
• Status Epilepticus is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment to prevent long-term damage or complications.
  • First-line treatment for acute management is benzodiazepines like Lorazepam, which should be administered first to quickly terminate the ongoing seizure activity.
  • After initial treatment with Lorazepam, the next step involves using anticonvulsants to prevent recurrence. Levetiracetam or Valproate can be used in this step, with Levetiracetam often preferred due to its favourable safety profile and rapid action.

General Management Protocol:

  1. First 5 minutes: Administer Lorazepam or another benzodiazepine.
  2. Following 5-20 minutes: Use a second-line antiepileptic drug such as Levetiracetam or Valproate if seizures persist.

Reference: IAP Standard Treatment Guidelines 2022 - Evaluation and Management of Status Epilepticus in Children, OP Ghai 10th Edition

questions.text: A 12-year-old male presents with a rough, raised, scaly, yellow-white lesion on the lower back. His mother reports intellectual disability and a recent episode of abnormal body movements lasting about 5 minutes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Shagreen Patch: A rough, raised, scaly, yellow-white lesion commonly associated with Tuberous Sclerosis.
  • Intellectual disability and seizures: Both are features seen in Tuberous Sclerosis, which is known for its neurological involvement.

CNS involvement + Skin manifestations like shagreen patch/ Adenoma

Sebaceum or Ash-leaf macules indicate Tuberous sclerosis as the likely possibility.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition

questions.text: A neonate delivered via normal vaginal delivery, who is started on mother's feed, develops vomiting, hypoglycemia, oil drop cataract, hepatomegaly, and mild icterus. Urine tests positive for reducing substances, but not glucose. What is the likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The presentation suggests Galactosemia, a condition caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase. This enzyme is crucial in the metabolism of galactose, and its deficiency leads to an accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the blood and tissues.

  • Vomiting, hypoglycemia, oil-drop cataract, hepatomegaly, and mild icterus: Common in galactosemia.
  • Urine positive for reducing substances, but not glucose: Indicates the presence of galactose or its metabolites, rather than glucose.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Chapter 105.2; OP Ghai 10th Edition, Page 687

questions.text: Vitamin B6 administration is helpful in which of the following metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is particularly useful in the management of Homocystinuria, especially the pyridoxine-responsive form. In these cases, vitamin B6 supplementation can help reduce homocysteine levels and improve clinical outcomes.

  • Homocystinuria: Treatment with vitamin B6 is effective in some patients, but dietary methionine restriction is also crucial to control plasma homocysteine levels.
  • Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH): Requires glucocorticoid therapy (like hydrocortisone), not vitamin B6.
  • Phenylketonuria (PKU): Managed by dietary restriction of phenylalanine, not by vitamin B6.
  • Alkaptonuria: Treated with Nitisinone to inhibit pigment production, not with vitamin B6.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Pages 684-685

choices.text: IgG Anti EMA + Total Serum IgA

questions.text: A child suspected of having Celiac disease is to be evaluated. Which of the following will be the first-line screening investigations you will advise, based on the latest guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to the latest ESPGHAN guidelines and Nelson's textbook, the first-line screening for suspected Celiac disease should include both IgA Tissue Transglutaminase (IgA TTG) and Total Serum IgA. This approach helps account for the potential presence of selective IgA deficiency, which can affect test accuracy.

  • IgA TTG is the primary antibody test used for screening.
  • Total Serum IgA is measured to rule out selective IgA deficiency, which can lead to false-negative results if only IgA TTG is used.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Page 320-322; Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 364

questions.text: The metabolic derangement in congenital pyloric stenosis is:
questions.solution:
In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the classic metabolic derangement observed is hypochloremic Hypokalaemia metabolic alkalosis. This occurs due to:

  • Loss of hydrochloric acid (HCl) from persistent vomiting associated with pyloric stenosis.
  • Hypochloremia results from the loss of chloride ions.
  • Alkalosis is due to the loss of hydrogen ions and the body's response to maintain pH balance.
  • Hypokalemia (low potassium levels) is often present as well.
  • The condition may also present with paradoxical aciduria (acidic urine despite systemic alkalosis).

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Page 295; Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 355

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with abdominal pain which was acute in nature, vomiting, and progressive lethargy. There was red-currant jelly stools and contrast enema revealed the coiled spring sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In typical cases of intussusception, there is sudden onset, in a previously well child, of severe paroxysmal colicky pain that recurs at frequent intervals and is accompanied by straining efforts with legs and knees flexed and loud cries.

At times, the lethargy is disproportionate to the abdominal signs. Eventually, a shock-like state, with fever and peritonitis, can develop.

Vomiting occurs in most cases and is usually more frequent in the early phase. In the later phase, the vomitus becomes bile stained. 60% of infants pass a stool containing red blood and mucus, the currant jelly stool.

The diagnostic findings of intussusception on ultrasound include a tubular mass in longitudinal views and a doughnut or target appearance in transverse images.

Contrast enemas demonstrate a filling defect or cupping in the head of the contrast media where its advance is obstructed by the intussusceptum

A central linear column of contrast media may be visible in the compressed lumen of the intussusceptum, and a thin rim of contrast may be seen trapped around the invaginating intestine in the folds of mucosa within the intussuscipiens (coiled-spring sign), especially after evacuation.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Pages 304-305

choices.text: Hemarthroses commonly occur in this disorder
Spontaneous recovery within several weeks is expected
Platelet transfusion should be urgently performed
Prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time are prolonged

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office with a few petechiae and bruising on the face, chest, back, and lower extremities, which her mother noticed early this morning. The mother states that her daughter has been healthy except for a viral upper respiratory illness 2 weeks ago. Laboratory assessment reveals a platelet count of 25,000/microlitre without any splenomegaly. Which of the following statements regarding the likely diagnosis is correct?
questions.solution:
• The presentation is consistent with acute idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), onset of petechia 2 weeks after the viral infection and platelet count showing thrombocytopenia.
  • Spontaneous recovery is typical, as many children with acute ITP recover within a few weeks without intervention.
  • Platelet transfusions are not indicated in ITP because the underlying issue is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets.
  • Prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are usually normal in ITP, as it is a problem of platelet destruction rather than coagulation factor deficiency.
  • Hemarthroses are more commonly associated with bleeding disorders like hemophilia, not ITP.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Page 372; ASH Guidelines 2019

questions.text: Trilateral retinoblastoma comprises bilateral retinoblastomas plus which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Trilateral retinoblastoma is characterized by bilateral retinoblastomas plus pineoblastoma (a type of neuroblastoma found in the pineal gland).
  • The association with osteosarcoma and other tumors like soft tissue sarcomas and malignant melanomas are seen in other forms of retinoblastoma but not in trilateral retinoblastoma.
  • Pineoblastoma typically presents as part of trilateral retinoblastoma and carries a poor prognosis.

Reference: OP Ghai 10th Edition, Page 635

choices.text: Administer a precordial thump and perform a jaw-thrust maneuver
Ask someone to retrieve an automatic external defibrillator (AED) and start chest compressions
Immobilize the cervical spine and attempt to palpate the carotid pulse
Perform rapid assessment of circulation/airway/breathing and call 108

questions.text: A 15-year-old adolescent collapses while playing in a high school basketball game without any preceding trauma. He is unconscious and not breathing. Of the following, the BEST sequence of actions is to?
questions.solution:
1. Unresponsive and Not Breathing: Begin CPR immediately as per PALS guidelines and OP Ghai 10th Edition.
  2. Call for AED: Request an AED to check for rhythm. VF (Ventricular Fibrillation) or pVT (Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia) requires an electric shock.
  3. CPR Details:
    • Push hard: To 1/3 of the anterior-posterior diameter of the chest.
    • Push fast: 100 compressions per minute.
    • Minimize interruptions and rotate personnel every 2 minutes.
  4. If Asystole or PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity): Administer epinephrine and continue CPR.
    • Avoid precordial thump and jaw-thrust maneuver unless indicated specifically.
    • Cervical spine immobilization and pulse palpation are secondary actions.

questions.text: What is an alternative method to measure height of a 4-year-old child?
questions.solution:
• CRL is used in the fetal period.
  • Knee length is sitting height measured from Knee to ground, not reliable.
  • Arm span at this age is almost equal to the height, hence it is the best answer.

Reference: Ghai Essential pediatrics, 8th ed., pg. 11

choices.text: Dried spot sample for HIV PCR

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant of an HIV positive mother presents with diarrhoea. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
• Gl infections are common with atypical organisms like cryptosporidium in HIV infants.
  • Breastfeeding must be continued in all infants as the advantages far outweighs the disadvantages.
  • For definitive diagnosis of HIV, DNA/RNA PCR is most specific. Antibody tests are used for screening only.

Reference: NACO guidelines for PPTCT

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with hypertension. On examination, lower limb pulsation was feeble, upper limb pulses were normal. On chest x-ray notching of the ribs were noted. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic sign of coarctation of the aorta is a disparity in pulsation and blood pressure in the arms and legs. The femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak (or absent in up to 40% of patients), in contrast to the bounding pulses of the arms and carotid vessels.

Chest X ray shows Notching of the inferior border of the ribs from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels is common by late childhood.

Reference: Ghai Essential pediatrics, 8th ed., pg. 431
